trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure DNS | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure DNS | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create DNS zones for Azure DNS step-by-step to start hosting your DNS domain using PowerShell or CLI
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create DNS zones for Azure DNS step-by-step to start hosting your DNS domain using PowerShell or CLI

trans-unit.source: The domain ‘contoso.com’ can contain a number of DNS records, such as ‘mail.contoso.com’ (for a mail server) and ‘www.contoso.com’ (for a website).
trans-unit.target: The domain ‘contoso.com’ can contain a number of DNS records, such as ‘mail.contoso.com’ (for a mail server) and ‘www.contoso.com’ (for a website).

trans-unit.source: A DNS zone is used to host the DNS records for a particular domain.
trans-unit.target: A DNS zone is used to host the DNS records for a particular domain.

trans-unit.source: To start hosting your domain, you first need to create a DNS zone.
trans-unit.target: To start hosting your domain, you first need to create a DNS zone.

trans-unit.source: Any DNS record created for a particular domain will be inside a DNS zone for the domain.
trans-unit.target: Any DNS record created for a particular domain will be inside a DNS zone for the domain.

trans-unit.source: These instructions use Microsoft Azure CLI.
trans-unit.target: These instructions use Microsoft Azure CLI.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to update to the latest Azure CLI to use the Azure DNS commands.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to update to the latest Azure CLI to use the Azure DNS commands.

trans-unit.source: Install Azure CLI.
trans-unit.target: Install Azure CLI.

trans-unit.source: You can install Azure CLI for Windows, Linux, or MAC.
trans-unit.target: You can install Azure CLI for Windows, Linux, or MAC.

trans-unit.source: The following steps need to be completed before you can manage Azure DNS using Azure CLI.
trans-unit.target: The following steps need to be completed before you can manage Azure DNS using Azure CLI.

trans-unit.source: More information is available at <linkText>Install the Azure CLI</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: More information is available at <linkText>Install the Azure CLI</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: All the network provider commands on CLI can be found using the following command:
trans-unit.target: All the network provider commands on CLI can be found using the following command:

trans-unit.source: The DNS commands require Azure CLI version 0.9.8 or above.
trans-unit.target: The DNS commands require Azure CLI version 0.9.8 or above.

trans-unit.source: Type azure -vto check which Azure CLI version is currently installed in your machine.
trans-unit.target: Type azure -vto check which Azure CLI version is currently installed in your machine.

trans-unit.source: Azure DNS uses Azure Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: Azure DNS uses Azure Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you switch CLI to use arm commands and DNS.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you switch CLI to use arm commands and DNS.

trans-unit.source: Sign in to your Azure account.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to your Azure account.

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to authenticate with your credentials.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to authenticate with your credentials.

trans-unit.source: Keep in mind that you can only use ORGID accounts.
trans-unit.target: Keep in mind that you can only use ORGID accounts.

trans-unit.source: Choose which of your Azure subscriptions to use.
trans-unit.target: Choose which of your Azure subscriptions to use.

trans-unit.source: To see a list of available subscriptions, use the "azure account list" command.
trans-unit.target: To see a list of available subscriptions, use the "azure account list" command.

trans-unit.source: Create a new resource group (skip this step if using an existing resource group)
trans-unit.target: Create a new resource group (skip this step if using an existing resource group)

trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Manager requires that all resource groups specify a location.
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Manager requires that all resource groups specify a location.

trans-unit.source: This is used as the default location for resources in that resource group.
trans-unit.target: This is used as the default location for resources in that resource group.

trans-unit.source: However, because all DNS resources are global, not regional, the choice of resource group location has no impact on Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: However, because all DNS resources are global, not regional, the choice of resource group location has no impact on Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: The Azure DNS service is managed by the Microsoft.Network resource provider.
trans-unit.target: The Azure DNS service is managed by the Microsoft.Network resource provider.

trans-unit.source: Your Azure subscription needs to be registered to use this resource provider before you can use Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: Your Azure subscription needs to be registered to use this resource provider before you can use Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: This is a one-time operation for each subscription.
trans-unit.target: This is a one-time operation for each subscription.

trans-unit.source: Tags are different from Etags.
trans-unit.target: Tags are different from Etags.

trans-unit.source: Tags are a list of name-value pairs, and are used by Azure Resource Manager to label resources for billing or grouping purposes.
trans-unit.target: Tags are a list of name-value pairs, and are used by Azure Resource Manager to label resources for billing or grouping purposes.

trans-unit.source: For more information about tags, see <linkText>Using tags to organize your Azure resources</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about tags, see <linkText>Using tags to organize your Azure resources</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Azure DNS CLI supports tags on both zones and record sets specified by using the options ‘-Tag’ parameter.
trans-unit.target: Azure DNS CLI supports tags on both zones and record sets specified by using the options ‘-Tag’ parameter.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to create a DNS zone with two tags, ‘project = demo’ and ‘env = test’:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to create a DNS zone with two tags, ‘project = demo’ and ‘env = test’:

trans-unit.source: A DNS zone is created using the azure network dns zone create command.
trans-unit.target: A DNS zone is created using the azure network dns zone create command.

trans-unit.source: In the example below, you create a DNS zone called 'contoso.com' in the resource group called 'MyResourceGroup':
trans-unit.target: In the example below, you create a DNS zone called 'contoso.com' in the resource group called 'MyResourceGroup':

trans-unit.source: In Azure DNS, zone names should be specified without a terminating ‘.’, for example, as ‘contoso.com’ rather than ‘contoso.com.’.
trans-unit.target: In Azure DNS, zone names should be specified without a terminating ‘.’, for example, as ‘contoso.com’ rather than ‘contoso.com.’.

trans-unit.source: Your DNS zone has now been created in Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: Your DNS zone has now been created in Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: Creating a DNS zone also creates the following DNS records:
trans-unit.target: Creating a DNS zone also creates the following DNS records:

trans-unit.source: The ‘Start of Authority’ (SOA) record.
trans-unit.target: The ‘Start of Authority’ (SOA) record.

trans-unit.source: This is present at the root of every DNS zone.
trans-unit.target: This is present at the root of every DNS zone.

trans-unit.source: The authoritative name server (NS) records.
trans-unit.target: The authoritative name server (NS) records.

trans-unit.source: These show which name servers are hosting the zone.
trans-unit.target: These show which name servers are hosting the zone.

trans-unit.source: Azure DNS uses a pool of name servers, and so different name servers can be assigned to different zones in Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: Azure DNS uses a pool of name servers, and so different name servers can be assigned to different zones in Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Delegate a domain to Azure DNS</linkText><title></title> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Delegate a domain to Azure DNS</linkText><title></title> for more information.

trans-unit.source: To view these records, use "azure network dns-record-set show":
trans-unit.target: To view these records, use "azure network dns-record-set show":

trans-unit.source: In the example below, running the command with resource group "myresourcegroup", record set name "@" (for a root record) and type "SOA" will yield the following output:
trans-unit.target: In the example below, running the command with resource group "myresourcegroup", record set name "@" (for a root record) and type "SOA" will yield the following output:

trans-unit.source: Record sets at the root (or ‘apex’) of a DNS zone use "@" as the record set name.
trans-unit.target: Record sets at the root (or ‘apex’) of a DNS zone use "@" as the record set name.

trans-unit.source: Having created your first DNS zone, you can test it by using DNS tools such as nslookup, DIG, or the Resolve-DnsName PowerShell cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Having created your first DNS zone, you can test it by using DNS tools such as nslookup, DIG, or the Resolve-DnsName PowerShell cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: If you haven’t yet delegated your domain to use the new zone in Azure DNS, you need to direct the DNS query directly to one of the name servers for your zone.
trans-unit.target: If you haven’t yet delegated your domain to use the new zone in Azure DNS, you need to direct the DNS query directly to one of the name servers for your zone.

trans-unit.source: The name servers for your zone are given in the NS records, as listed by "azure network dns-record-set show" above.
trans-unit.target: The name servers for your zone are given in the NS records, as listed by "azure network dns-record-set show" above.

trans-unit.source: Be sure the substitute the correct values for your zone in the command below.
trans-unit.target: Be sure the substitute the correct values for your zone in the command below.

trans-unit.source: The following example uses DIG to query the domain contoso.com using the name servers assigned for the DNS zone. The query has to point to a name server for which we used @ and zone name using DIG.
trans-unit.target: The following example uses DIG to query the domain contoso.com using the name servers assigned for the DNS zone. The query has to point to a name server for which we used @ and zone name using DIG.

trans-unit.source:
